Have you read The Circle, yet?

@WebStormIDE Wrong link?
@ghosh1s Sure. I will have a tutorial ready soon, btw.
@Lynoure It does not feel like that. I have no restraints to share within the organization, so I think this facilitates transparency.

@mirjam_diala @FinjaReloaded

The quality of the video here is not so good, but he gives a good introduction to TDD: https://t.co/gpPRb6KAvR

@mirjam_diala @FinjaReloaded IMHO This book (if you prefer to read) is one of the best introductions to TDD: https://t.co/bK0CSlcHAr

It has "Object Oriented" in the title, but the basic techniques can also be applied for more functional software.
@mirjam_diala @FinjaReloaded Also, follow @ministryoftest for a lot of awesome content around testing.

@FinjaReloaded @mirjam_diala Sure! If you have questions or anything else, feel free to reach out.

If you are looking for a community of 3,000 nice humans who love TDD, come join the Software Crafters Slack and one of our local communities and conferences: https://t.co/zCoTsgR8yL

For me writing tests means I use at least two brains, they might be the same (still mine) but it adds a second, and important step to the act of writing code: declaring the intention. https://t.co/eGk3Juq8i6

On what's wrong in Silicon Valley:
"The endless use of ‚Äúscale‚Äù as an excuse for being unable to solve problems in a human way. The faux earnestness, the self-righteousness. All those cheery product ads set to ukulele music." https://t.co/tn8NT8eeri https://t.co/QpKmMUNGZG

Today is
Release Day!
I will have new #iot stuff to share later for @NordicTweets https://t.co/RbdiKQqs4W ... now going to spin me up some serverless.
@benjamin Yes. More servers, which are not servers. One could think that we had better words for what we are doing, but ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è.

Things that took longer than expected with today's deployment: 
- migrating from manual config to infrastructure as code means you have to clean up old cruft properly beforehand
- migrations on production datasets did take surprisingly long

Aaaand here it is: üéâ
Our first release of the @NordicTweets #nRFConnect Device API!
Connect your #BLE, #LTE or any other device to our free #IoT development platform and interact with that device through a straight-forward #RESTful #API.
Get started on https://t.co/uZ6OTS8m9C > https://t.co/dEWBILt6kr
We have examples for accessing Bluetooth Low Energy services through our mobile gateways (available for Android and iOS): https://t.co/MX3V1z4Vnf #BLE

Or you can use the @NordicTweets Thingy:52 to receive alerts via webhooks (e.g. in @SlackHQ) if the temperature rises above a certain level: https://t.co/pLI2V2sCFo
#thingy52

Last and probably most exciting is the ability to connect to our API with MQTT using your own custom device, or one of our #LTE or #NBIOT DKs (if you are lucky and can get your hands on the #nRF91): 
https://t.co/as4ToveWE3

I'm eager for any kind of feedback! Please hit me with any small or big thing that you can think of! The project is in an early stage and your feedback will have a big impact.
You can reach me via DM and on our official support platform: https://t.co/gln6XrvCvU #LeanStartup
Happy connecting! https://t.co/m0nXXdew0x

Visiting my friends @Code_Door who give refugees and members of underrepresented groups free coding education.
This is a fantastic project where I am giving remote support via Slack these days, so it's a welcome change to see the students in person again. https://t.co/xddqDBXq8N

I'm a digital muli. https://t.co/4NHJJvoy1g

@jscamp I think most interesting will be to see if #webassembly become widely accepted and we can build safer, more performant and richer web applications and how we can transition more JS developers to safer languages (üëã Rust).

@jscamp Node.js 10 (follow @fhinkel) will become LTS and I am looking forward to more codebases migrating to this version. 
I hope we will see a new discussion around writing Vanilla JS (I do love TypeScript but it's hard to get it right).

@jscamp @fhinkel I am excited about @npmjs hiring 7+ people and looking forward what they will do to improve my daily live as a CI/CD fanatic. @maybekatz is one who should be followed, I do run her code every day.

@jscamp My challenge is to find the balance between the ability to evolve our codebase and keep everything working in a cloud-native environment where I no longer have one node process but hundreds of decoupled execution environments.
One of the big fallacies of #agile IMO: a completed sprint is seen as a deliverable by itself, sometimes even as the most important one. https://t.co/axqhnw73cr

I will be in the "What's the best backend language?" panel representing #JavaScript @codetalkshh this week.
I have an opinion (and shared some of it here: https://t.co/u5oZ1ujXYQ) but I would really like to hear what you have to say!
Why do you prefer JavaScript for your backend?

I recently realized that #impact (as in the number of users using the result of my work) is the single greatest source of satisfaction for me.
I love to implement complex solutions, automate and continuously deliver.
But if I deliver into a vacuum the joy I feel is short lived. https://t.co/kzVT7Qe529

The @RuhrJS videos are coming in: https://t.co/2EjjLIbOqt
#ruhrjs18

Cool! GitHub offers a task runner: https://t.co/gjGbO40KCV
It will be interesting to see how they mix testing and deployment statuses in a user-friendly way.
I like the separation: GitHub receives test results for the code, but deployment results are a different concern.
But it will make continuous deployment way more approachable for many developers, which is awesome!
